CairoVM GO Status (https://www.notion.so.Status Context: All pending PRs were merged. We added new test cases, now we have around 150 from 70 that we had before. There is an issue with dict relocation which is causing some tests not to pass, so we are working to fix those atm. Only 13 test are not passing. The comparison with the other VMs for the rest of the tests is successful. We are running benchmarks next week and fixing last details. The plan is to show results to SW in the Thursday call.

All major features have been completed! We’ve been going over the comparisons of the outputs against other VMs, this has uncovered a few small bugs which we’ve been fixing. The PRs are up for review, so they’ll need to be merged.
We’ll continue with the rest of the tests and run benchmarkings for next week.
We looked into the changes made by SW team on cairo-executable crate, and it’s been decided to wait for the oficial release from SW to include the changes on our side as they are still modifying the code. More details in https://demerzelsolutions.slack.com/archives/C05K8D4SM5Z/p1738754716562329.

- Infrastructure for comparisons with other VMs is in place and merged (it also includes some refactoring on the old implementation of the test suit)
- All the entry point function modifications have been made regarding proof mode
- The other changes regarding proof mode were inside the runner function (also finished):
   - Dictionaries reallocation in memory ✅
   - Builtin finalization ✅
Now we’ll be focusing on testing, comparisons and benchmarkings.

We’ve been tracking progress on the Cairo-executable crate the SW team has been working on for the past month. They have added the binary that would allow us to get the serialized output from the compilation, up until now we had a fork of their repo and an implementation from our side that we were using, so we’ll be checking that out to replace this step in the current pipeline to use theirs

1. Changes regarding the inputs for the main function were merged.
2. For proof mode, we have to:
- Implement changes to the entry point preparation function. This is almost finished, only missing some details regarding Segment Arena builtin.
- Add some additional features and checks in the runner function (currently being worked on).
3. Regarding the comparison against other VMs this is the situation: 
We have the LC rust VM that supports proof mode, passing arguments to the main function, but does not support gas related operations. And there is the SW rust VM which does not allow passing arguments to the main function through the cli command, doesn’t have proof mode, but does include all gas calculations. Now, our VM supports everything, so for doing the final comparison we decided to: check Execution mode with gas against SW, and proof mode and arguments to main against LC. The infrastructure for this is mostly built already, so as soon as proof mode is done, we’ll start the process of comparisons.

From the main strands of work mentioned in the last status report:
- Dictionaries were fixed and implemented changes were merged
- All proof mode differences have been identified and the team has started working on them already
Besides this, the functionality to add user arguments to the main function has been completed, specifically the loading on memory of more complex structures (arrays). This is under review.
We’ll be focusing on implementing the changes needed for proof mode in Cairo 1, and fix the testing suit to be able to compare the final result with the one of other VMs

Other bugs found in testing were addressed:
- Gas segment allocation with token gas cost
- ECDSA hints fixed
There are two main strands of work atm:
- Dictionaries are not behaving correctly, it appears this is due to Segment Arena builtin.
- Proof mode differences between zero version and current one are causing the program to fail in this mode.  First we need to identify those differences and then implement them

Previous PRs for adding extra functionalities have been merged.
Out of 74 Cairo 1 programs for testing, more than 90% are currently executing successfully. Only 6 remain to be fixed. The team is still looking into the issue with proof mode.

Note: As for the holidays most of the team is going off for a few days, so only Maksym will be working on it, which means progress might be a bit slower. Next status review will be added on Friday Jan 10th.

Several fixes done to the pipeline during this week:
1. Loading gas and entrypoints arguments to the execution segment after builtins pointer
2. Using only builtins present in program builtins field in Execution mode
3. Modifying the keys in the hintmap by the size of entry code instructions
Some refactorings of the code were made and extra functionalities added to the cli:
- Add option for passing arguments to main function
- Add option for passing available_gas to the runner
(All these are under review process)

Non-complex tests are passing now. We are focusing atm on solving that some programs are failing at the last instruction in proof_mode and not in execution_mode

The main bug mentioned last week turned out to be a problem updating the correct registers. This has been addressed. The work now is focused on two different strands:
- There seems to be a problem with memory accesses inside the runner which we are looking into.
- Some cases that were not supported by our Hint Parser were identified, so we are working on the logic to add them.

The structure for running integration tests has been put in place. We’ve added around 75 cairo 1 programs from other VMs in current use. There is a problem with memory allocation that is preventing the files to pass the test atm, and this is currently being addressed. The plan this week is to fix this problem and separate the tests into different batches to identify and address all the bugs that appear during the testing process, and so start working on 2 different batches at least.

No issues, the team has now landed after Devcon.

- The problem with the generated bytecode has been solved and a PR has been raised to the branch of the author of the SW repo’s PR. It’s currently undergoing review
- PR raised for separating the commands to run Cairo 0 and Cairo 1 files
- Some more refactorings and optimizations done in the code as a result of profiling and benchmarking. Apparently all the changes to be made forward are non trivial. Currently studying possible optimizations using Go assembly
- Progressing on the gas task

- Although the programs run correctly in the runner, the output that’s being generated with the PR (for Cairo output as a json in SW repo) is different from the one generated by the rust vm. Someone on the team is looking into it
- Studying gas counting mechanism to know what needs to be implemented. Notes on how it works are being written https://www.notion.so/2ee0a39343ce49f1894aa1a21c8d92ac?pvs=21 
- Profiling and benchmarking of the code to identify possible areas for optimization, a first PR with the obvious changes was already merged

- We had to rework the logic of Mod builtins, as there were some bugs in our implementation. All the work regarding this has been merged along with several test cases.
- We started looking into Direct Threaded Dispatch which is one of the ideas for optimizing the handling of instructions and hints. This should improve the performance of the VM. As for now, we’ve only started studying how it works, we haven’t made yet any changes to the code.
- We started the work to add the option to the cli to run main passing parameters. It’s possible to define the main function with input arguments, but the rust vm by SW does not allow to pass them through the run command. We’ve already defined the necessary steps to add this feature and will be working on it next week.

There are 2 blockers for the rest of the work we need to do:
1- The input bytecode that we get from the PR to the starkware repo to obtain the casm output as a json does not match the bytecode generated by the rust vm. Even though the runner works fine, this means we cannot do any testing of it until this is solved.
2- There is an option to pass the available gas for a program through the cli, which implies we should implement the gas counting mechanism for programs as well. However apparently for the first calculations we need some metadata from the sierra output, and currently we just receive the casm output. Once we decide the best way to obtain this information we should be able to implement this feature.

The team faced a difficult situation this week. Basically the team has reduced and was also focusing on Blockifier in Go project at the same time, so there was not too much progress on this front. It’s been decided to stop Blockifier project for a few weeks so all the focus would be only on the VM and implementing the main functionalities needed for the Cairo 1 runner. We’ll be focusing on research for the next week to be able to provide a clear list of tasks for the work remaining and help the junior team members to better understand the work they have to do.

Progress this week was very slow (most of the team was off). The PR for air inputs got merged. The team is currently working on:
- the inconsistency between rust vm and the bytecode we get from our pipeline is being researched
- adding some post checks for builtins
Regarding both tasks, the team is struggling with the lack of documentation from SW, hence it’s been slower than expected.
We should continue the work on these two items next week and move on with more complex files
In addition, some refactorings were made to the code.

- The team’s been working on the testing for the mod builtins (still undergoing review). This feature was added to the current rust runner very recently, so we are still trying to figure out how to go about the testing.
-  Implemented all functionalities needed to get air public and private inputs, which have to be fed to the prover, and added the option to the cli. PR is still undergoing review.
-  We've been working with a simple cairo 1 file (fibonacci) that doesn't require hints or builtins. Manually loading everything, it runs correctly. However, there is an issue regarding the instruction bytecode we get as input. Once that is solved we should start checking more complex files and eventually add a similar integration test suit for cairo 1 that checks the correct behavior of all hints and builtins.
- All different layouts have been added.

The two mod builtins and the EvalCircuit hint that was dependent on them have been implemented. The PR is still undergoing review because the testing is still being worked on. These are the last builtins and hint pending for cairo 1 files execution (not smart contract).
There’s also a PR to add the AIR private inputs and outputs as an option in the CLI.
A big refactoring of the code was merged to unify the types for operanders. This change makes the code look a lot cleaner and allowed us to remove several type assertions, which could influence the performance.
Still looking into the changes needed in the pipeline of the runner to reuse as much as possible from the zero runner

The PRs in review from last week have been merged, which included: the new grammar for parsing cairo zero references (that solved the final bugs in integration tests), the structure for building cairo 1 hint map along with unit tests, and another of the missing hints, which leaves only one more to be implemented (the one that’s blocked).
Regarding builtins, they were 3 missing, one of them is already completed. The other two are needed for EvalCircuit hint. There is a draft PR for them already, it still needs testing and then should be ready for review. In addition, there is an open PR for adding the layouts to the code that use the new implemented builtins.
While investigating the pipeline for the runner, we’ll be able to reuse most of the zero runner, there are almost no changes in instructions or the functions that need to be called for execution.

The remaining bug for Cairo zero hints has been fixed, the PR is undergoing review. This means all integration tests are passing and marks the zero runner as completed 🎉.

Regarding Cairo 1 work, so far:
- There are 3 hints that we need to implement, one was completed this week, the second one has an open PR (in review) and the remaining one is blocked due to missing builtins.
- There are 3 builtins missing, all of them are being worked on atm.
- The structure to build the hint map for Cairo 1 in the hintrunner out of the compiled output of a program needed to be implemented. There is a PR for that already, also in review.
For next week we’ll be focusing on the research of instructions and the pipeline for the runner. 

In addition, it was brought up that the prover needed AIR inputs and outputs, instead of the trace directly, so the team is looking into that and implementing the necessary changes.

All hint implementations were finally completed which adds to a total of 142 hints. Integration tests were added for all of them, only two remain failing, due to the same bug, which is already being worked on. 
The rest of the team already started looking into what’s needed for Cairo 1 runner. There are 2 main issues to work on at the moment, which should allow us to create more specific tasks: 
- Investigate the pipeline of the cairo 1 runner in the rust vm, which should uncover the differences in instructions, the initialization of segments and builtins, steps to run, etc.
- Build a map for cairo 1 hints, as the current one is only for cairo 0

After running integration tests, around 30 hints were discovered missing (most of them were different versions of the ones we already had implemented). All but 3 were implemented during last week and merged, the rest are still on review. Regarding bugs found, only the one regarding the parsing of hint references remain to be fixed, which is expected for early next week, since it requires a lot of changes to the codebase. The team has also worked on parallelizing the execution of integration tests, so it doesn’t take as long; there is a PR for that already. The timeline for the project has been adjusted to include all of the findings and fixes required during the testing process, so Cairo 1 runner effort is suppose to start in a week time.

The team continues to make progress on integration tests. We’ve figured out how the whitelisted hints are distributed in the cairo lang repository, so we’ve been able to add to the list all the hints that were still missing. There are like +30. Fortunatelly most of them are just different versions of the ones we already have, which means there are practically no modification to do to the code, and they should be implemented rather quickly.
Regarding bugs, we have some issues detailing the errors we’ve gotten. Apparently some of them are related to fetching the references for the hints from the compiled json output. Three of them have already been solved. There are two more that should be solved extending the grammar for the parsing of the references, which is being worked on atm.

This week progress was slow, as the team was unable to work on the project (Carmen at EthCC, Tristan was supposed to be at EthCC but had problems with the trains, Shogo had to be hospitalized, Maks was working part time and only Hari was able to keep working fully on it). There are still some bugs that need to be fixed in order for all the integration tests to pass. The worst of them has to do with the parsing of the hint references, which could lead to modifications in the codebase. The fact that the team is focused on finishing integration tests has prevented us from starting on Cairo 1 runner, which should be started already.

The team successfully fixed all bugs regarding blake hints. During keccak investigation it was noticed that there were some hints missing, those were also implemented during the week and merged. There are four integration test files for keccak that have some bugs with memory, but it appears to be the same underlying bug, we are already looking into it. There is another issue to check regarding Poseidon builtin, which is also being looked at atm.
There is a pr regarding the output for cairo 1 files, which we’ve been following up, since this will be needed for the cairo 1 runner. We have been working on a detailed task list for developing cairo 1 runner, which we should be starting next week

Most of the integration tests for hints have been merged already but the ones regarding blake and keccak related hints. There are open PRs for them already but the team is investigating some bugs that appeared with these tests. Once all these tests are completed, phase 2 of the roadmap will be completed as well.
We should start focusing on building the cairo 1 runner for next week.

Team has been focusing on integration tests for all of the hints. The work has already uncover a few more hints that needed to be implemented, and so we’ve done. All integration tests are expected to be finished by the end of next week

- We’ve stabilized our dev environments and pushed our long awaited release to master. This allows us to do final testing for RPC SaaS payment related features and continue work on improving our SDLC with a single branch strategy as a starter.
- In the coming weeks, we need to focus on improving latency across several pages, primarily focussing on the latency of API calls.
- Related to the above, Braavos has started testing the newly created API endpoint. Formalizing a deal turns out to be premature as we need to ensure our infra is production grade for the anticipated load. This will delay the deal.
- Ad revenue share is no longer on the table, yet we continue to work on this as monetization on all fronts becomes an important pillar in Voyager. Dockerizing Voyager is become urgent since we’ve gotten requests from a few companies on L2/L3’s.
- Voyager got exposure due to 4844 and the London events.
- New hire (dev lead) will be onboarded next week.

- It took us till today to stabilize our dev environment. We will release next Monday. The release includes RPC SaaS payment items, performance improvements and a range of new features and feature improvements.
- On the SDLC side we will move to the single branch strategy after our next release. We’ll be working on formalizing March release.
- On the infra side, we need to reconsider the amount of network + env combinations we maintain. We can possibly do cost saving on the infra side, as well as decrease test efforts while retaining test quality.
- We had a promising meet with Braavos’ CEO and CTO. They are looking to strengthen the relationship with Nethermind on all fronts, including Voyager. It’s possible that in the near future we can become the default block explorer in the wallet. This goes hand in hand with a proposed ad revenue share deal.

Delay in our planned, unusually large release due to unforeseen bugs. These are quickly being addressed and we should be able to release next week, after we stabalized our dev environment. 
Due to the nature of this release and the issues we are facing, we are expediting the change in process to work with a single branch. We will start formalizing this next week.

In summary the instrument and fund were deployed within 2 days, delaying current work around 2-5 days, and with around 3-7 days of work still pending to have the Instrument "correct".

We have a holiday calendar in place, but this does not seem to have helped with the planning aspect. The issue is mostly on the Libre side, but regardless it does not create a good working environment for everyone, and it has involved Yehia and I directly on the Nethermind side as well.

Juno status (https://www.notion.so/Juno-.Status Context:
- Blockifier updates PR was finally merged
- The implementation for estimate_fee is up in a draft, currently being tested. As we’ll be doing the release in the first half of next week, there is a possibility that we’ll have to add more testing in the following release.
A lot of effort on testing also has gone to make sure the changes in RPC package are working properly. We have identified and fixed a lot of bugs in this stage.
Running some benchmarks on Thursday, we realized a change was introduced that affected our performance by 2.5x. This, along with the estimate_fee PR, are the main priorities for the next release. If we keep up the same pace, everything should go as expected.

We have added 2 new members to the team: Dat and Bohdan. Both are going through the onboarding package. We expect 2 more people to join by next week.

Regarding next release:
- Websocket updates due to latest changes in the spec has been completed and merged
- There was a big refactor of the RPC package to allow the support for multiple version of rpc, specifically to add 0.6 back as requested by SW team.
- The PR for blockifier updates is still under review.
Two out of the 3 pendings we mention from last week have been completed, we are still on track for the release.

- There are two members of the team that went off this week Aneeque and Han. Han should be back on Tuesday and Aneeque around Feb 14
- Three members of the team (Rodrigo, Aneeque and Rian) attended Consensus Summit on Jan 27-28 with SW team and the rest of full node clients. It was a very productive meeting. It was discussed the roadmap of SW for this year, P2P status, consensus implementation. Juno will continue to work as a full node client and will go ahead with the Tendermint implementation in go for Consensus instead of integrating Malachite.
- Regarding next release:
    - Changes due to updates on the Blockifier will be separated into three PRs:
        1- Update blockifier in VM package (already in review)
        2- Implement estimate_fee (in progress)
        3- Cairo Native integration (low priority, does not have to be included in this release)
    - Due to latest spec we need to update websocket implementation. Aneeque was working on this but couldn’t finish before going off, so Han would be picking this up once he returns on Tuesday.
    - As requested by SW team, we’ll be adding version 0.6 support again. This work was being done by Daniil, but will be taken over by Rian since Daniil is already working on blockifier updates.
- For the sequencing PRs, the genesis one is already approved but waiting for PRs 1 and 2 from blockifier updates to go in first

SW release has been postponed for at least another week. Also Blockifier release is still not out, so we decided to start working on the latest commit to have the work ready for when that happens.
- PR regarding getStorageProof  has been merged, which was the last endpoint that had to be implemented for rpc new version.
- Significant changes to gas price handling, particularly l2 gas, have been implemented and merged. This is also needed for rpc update.

For the next release we still have to work on:
- Changes for the blockifier new version, this is being worked on atm
- It was asked by SW team to keep version 0.6 along with 0.7 and 0.8 for the next release, so we’ll need to work on that. There should be time for that as the date for the release will be later than expected.

Regarding sequencing:
- the mempool related PR has been merged, 
- the one for genesis state has been approved. However, it will not be merged until after the changes for the new blockifier version are implemented and merged (which takes priority), since this will bring changes to the VM package and probably will cause conflict with this PR.

Regarding next release:
- Implementation for getStorageProof endpoint has been completed and is under review process
Other changes have been merged as well:
- Modifications to subscribeTransactionStatus endpoint
- Store empty pending block and state
And minor fixes:
- Prevent panic in TransactionByHash fro non-existent transactions
- Update block parameter name as per v0.8.0-rc1

Note: Once SW releases new blockifier version (expected today or on Monday at most), the team has to work on Native integration. It’ll be decided then whether to include this changes in the coming release or do a second release after this one.

In the mean time there are some other efforts being worked on atm that will be the focus after the release:
- Sequencing work is being reviewed for merging. It was decided to separate the changes into different PRs to make the process of review easier and more atomic. Currently there are two PRs open, one for mempool implementation and another for genesis state. The rest of the changes are still not submitted.
- Database improvements (https://www.notion.so/17b360fc38d080c5aa2df91afce7f971?pvs=21). The first changes are being implemented atm and they should also do some benchmarking to make sure the changes are actually improving performance. Preliminary benchmarks have been done and are showing great results already.

Regarding next release:

- Progress in getStorageProof endpoint
This last feature is the main one that needs to get finished in order to do the release, which is scheduled to be no later than the end of the month, so we are on track.

dYdX Rust Client status (https://www.not.Status Context: The new feature is implemented - the permissionless market creation method was added: https://github.com/dydxprotocol/v4-clients/pull/304
The new version is released, and new methods added to provide the MegaVault feature support: https://github.com/dydxprotocol/v4-clients/pull/300#
We are in the maintenance phase. This week we sent an update to the crate, and also shared ownership to the library (in the registry) with new members of the dYdX team.
We have been approved to transition to the maintenance phase. I’ve left the status as amber for now to ensure we don’t forget to formalize it legally.

In dYdX, there have been team reshuffles, and the client is less active in communication. However, they did respond to the latest report, and now we are waiting for their response regarding the transition to the support phase. I’ve set the status to yellow since we haven’t officially moved to the next phase yet. Nevertheless, there are currently no additional tasks or expenses for the project, and all developers are engaged in other projects.

The project has been successfully completed, and two crates have been published on http://crates.io/: a protocol crate for Rust and a client library. However, we have not yet received official confirmation to move into the maintenance phase, which is complicated by significant personnel changes at dYdX (that's the reason of the yellow status). We are already operating in a maintenance mode and are not allocating resources to development.

Our developments have been merged both into the main repository with the clients and into the protocol. Essentially, our work has been accepted, and now we are waiting for the library release on http://crates.io/.
The main PR with the Rust client has merged to the official dYdX repo 🥳 The PR for the chain is not merged yet, but when it will be merged they can release the client on http://crates.io/.

• I decided to change the status to amber to draw attention to the lack of activity from dYdX. On the one hand, this delays the release, but on the other hand, the technical part is fully implemented, and any remarks or the release itself can be handled during the maintenance phase. It might make sense to check when our official completion date is and start discussing with them the receipt of the confirmation documents and payment (if we haven’t received them yet). This might motivate them to approve the work.
• As for the project itself, we conducted two fundamental experiments: the implementation of the C interface (successful, but the amount of work could justify a separate project) and we also launched the library in a WASM virtual machine, which allows the library to be used in a browser (we're including this experiment in the current release).

• We have received the first feedback, and it is positive.
• There was one question regarding the use of a library from C#, but this is not the recommended approach, so we decided to propose developing a separate .NET version.
• At the moment, all efforts are focused on the project release. In the upcoming week, we will work on merging our changes with the protocol (they have already been approved but not yet merged) and pushing the client's code to the main dYdX repository.

The repository is currently under review by the client. We're waiting for feedback. We'll remind them on Monday if we don't hear back.Meanwhile, we continue to improve the client: added Sequencers that allow generating ids for orders by time (this feature was recently introduced in the TS client).We conducted a full code review. Next week, we plan to do some refactoring, which will make the code even more compact. Overall, we are in the releasing phase and waiting for the feedback.

We've shared both repositories (chain - protocol updates, and client), and waiting for the feedback from the customer. We are also continuing to improve the client library with small adjustments since the main part of the work is completed. The client might want to change something, and we have just enough time left for that.

The client has been assigned a person for code review, and we are waiting for the branch with protocol support to be merged. We have added documentation to the project and another trading example. We also implemented the Noble Client (this part is not covered by tests in the clients, but we will consider if it's possible to do so in the Rust version).

The client library is ready, and we’ve tested all parts. We’ve started documenting it and are conducting experiments for further collaboration. Since we’re close to finalizing the work, we’re now waiting for them to add protocol support for Rust (we’ve submitted a PR). Next week, we’ll hand over the repository with the client for their review.

Context:
1. We have fully developed the client (all functions and examples are implemented).
2. Now we are debugging it and making it more convenient for development. Since Rust is a systems programming language, we need to add a high-level abstraction layer to make the library as easy to use as in other languages.
3. Our test account is up and running, everything is good.
4. We made the first PR to the exchange's chain repository, adding Rust support to the protocol. Once this part is released, we will be able to share the repository with the client.

• All methods and clients have been implemented. This week, we implemented examples, and we also started cleaning up everything and adding convenient types for working with the library.
• Blocker: A potential issue is that the test account has no funds, and the faucet is not working. I will write a request to the client to see if they can resolve this. If they can't, I will change the status to Amber and explore alternative testing methods, such as deploying a devnet.

The dYdX Rust client library replicates key features of the Python and TypeScript libraries, enabling interactions with dYdX's Indexer and Node services.

Supports REST API and WebSocket interactions for real-time market data and account management, with data returned as Rust structs.

Node interactions use gRPC for transactions and data retrieval, with a focus on transaction sequencing.

The library is primarily asynchronous, validated through unit testing, and based on the tokio crate.

Future plans include completing Node methods, integrating faucet testing, and developing a basic trading example.

Context:
• We've implemented the IndexerClient completely: all get methods and WebSocket streams
• Implemented 3 get methods in the NodeClient
• And the place_order to the NodeClient
• Implemented the Wallet and address derivation
• All the methods are covered with tests
• The protocol compilation to Rust (v4-chain repo) is improved
• The next week we will finish the basic implementation of all parts. After that we will start implementing the first, but essential trading example

Starknet Blockifier in Go staus (https:/.Status Context: Project on hold until CairoVM is finalized.
Project on hold until CairoVM in Go is stable
Project put on hold to focus on CairoVM stabilization

The basic layout for the following has been implemented:
- BlockInfo
- Class
- State (regarding StateDiff, State Update, and the interface to interact with the state)
From the types that are passed as parameters in the main functions of the blockifier module, we are only missing to define the layout for CallInfo and TransactionTrace. This, however, is part of the result of those functions, so we should start looking into the pipeline for the execution next.

It has been decided to stop the project for a few weeks:
- The current team working on it has reduced and is also working on the Cairo VM in Go project, so we’ll be prioritizing this one instead.
- Some people from the Cairo Native integration project are also expected to join the team for the Blockifier, but they also have their hands full atm with that one.
Once the situation with the other projects stabilizes, we should continue the work. As for the moment all PRs have been completed so there won’t be any unfinished work when we start again.

The team started working on the basic structures indicated in the basic layout. As for the moment all types of transaction have been implemented:
- Declare
- Invoke
- DeployAccount
- L1Handler
We have already started looking into other structs such as BlockInfo and CallInfo , which should be implemented early next week

The repository has been created and set up, along with a task board for the project.
A basic layout for the project structure is already in place. Initial CI to check linting also has been added.
There are some issues created which should be the focus of the team for next week:
- Adding the basic structures needed
- Define pipeline for execution methods

Creating the basic frontend structure for the ZenBTC app. This will continue into next week and at the end of next week the project will terminate as initially planned.

Delivered more changes to the labels implementation due to the backend changing. Addressing the mobile wallet connection issue that arose while working on the UI for mobile. Doing small tweaks here and there to bring the quality of the final product to as high standard as possible.

We have completed or are finalizing the next batch of functionality like the label fallback mechanism or responsive web design. The contract will still be running for four more weeks and we asked the client for guidance on the subsequent priorities.

We have delivered the last two items for the prototype: labels and notifications. The client is well-pleased and will present the prototype this weekend at their booth during Token2049. This delivery is a project milestone, so next week we will reorganize ourselves a bit and plan subsequent deliveries.

Completed the backend work around the API - this will now have to be used on the frontend side so the labels appear in the UI instead of addresses. We plan to complete this part of work by Tuesday next week and this will conclude the prototype. The prototype is supposed to be shown by the client during Token2049 in their booth in the final days of next week. After next week work will be reorganized and will continue for another 4 weeks in order to further tweak and optimize the app design.
Completed a bunch of tabs / views related to landing page, members page, workspace creation and overview. Work is proceeding as expected with no highlightable risks.

We have finished the data manipulation part and UI/UX work is underway. We obtained the first pack of designs and parallelized the work on different sections / views. We are now on schedule and seem confident we can deliver what is required on time as long as the designs keep flowing in.

• All methods and clients have been implemented. This week, we implemented examples, and we also started cleaning up everything and adding convenient types for working with the library.
• Blocker: A potential issue is that the test account has no funds, and the faucet is not working. I will write a request to the client to see if they can resolve this. If they can't, I will change the status to Amber and explore alternative testing methods, such as deploying a devnet.

• Jason’s perspective moved from “we must deliver the high prio features by token2049” to “we want to be able to demo some of the features”.
• The process to create a complete design system takes 12 weeks. Delphi will do a sprint to deliver some low fidelity designs for Token2049. A marathon will be going on in parallel to create the entire design system
• They’ll start with designing the basic items: landing page, workspace page, showing balances, policies, etc.
• The App Marketplace designs will come later.
• We’ll see the first designs/wireframes in around 2 weeksConclusions:
• There are roughly 4 weeks left before Token2049
• We can expect designs in 2 weeks
• My intuition says the app marketplace won’t be ready by Token2049 due to designs not being available soon enough.

There is no immediate danger to the project, however after some initial work it turned out that a bigger UI redesign will be required and Zenrock will engage their partner Delphi to provide the designs. We have decoupled the data manipulation parts from the UI parts. We are now working with the data manipulation tasks and should be fine until the end of next week. However, we should monitor the readiness of UI designs, as if not delivered on time, it might cause a block and delay in our work.
Initial project scope & estimates have been accepted. The contract has been signed and the delivery is beginning. Next week a more detailed work breakdown structure will be provided.

Colin’s update:

Progress has continued. On Monday I'd be happy to:
• review my work to date
• start sketching an AVSVault contract / interface that serves as a withdrawalHelper target for avs sponsored assets
• managing the AVS's outgoing IOUs (potentially via a similar merklized earnings tree to the EigenLayer core payments model)

• get clarity on the distinctions between an avs and an operator

On my plate between now and that meeting:

Proceeding as expected. We have added some fixes in binary reproducibility and improvements in local testing. Now we also have a deployment utility and a TDX VM running our custom image in Azure.

Last week, a kick-off session was held to determine the approaches to follow (details https://www.notion.so/252718dff08b4dafa32ec5ff915b6f27?pvs=21). As a first approach, we will attempt to run the Nethermind client on TDX, following an experiment from Flashbots.

RPC SaaS Status (https://www.notion.so/R.Status Context: Mitigation plan is being prioritized, Bravoos keeps sending 3x the traffic and all systems green
Bravoos continues to generate lots of traffic, and infra is holding up well.
We are noticing a slight uptick in traffic from Bravoos, and our infrastructure seems to be handling this well. Still yellow because mitigation plan not yet begun.
Node upgrades to latest versions performed and executed, issues with Bravoos still remain. Mitigation plan is being refined.

The RPC SaaS is currently operating well, but the high load conditions persist when Bravoos hits us with high traffic.

We have initiated a mitigation planning, which resulted into three distinct strategies which can be implemented in sequence.

- Bucketing requests similar to how Blast API does it
- Bucketing requests using heurstics provided by Juno

These two strategies will result in Kong plugins which will shape traffic routing from the loadbalancer

A third strategy has been identified as a DevOps solution, which involves creating a datacenter edition of Juno which uses a shared database, thus reducing spawn time of a k8s pod and reduces infra costs as storage requirements decrease from 1 DB per pod to 1 DB per cluster.

Overall Status: 🟡 The RPC project remains at Amber due to ongoing performance challenges related to heavy multi-call operations. The team had done the investigating potential solutions for increasing HAP scale times, but there is no positive result. Only minor improvement found could be done by updating a juno configuration for less failed requests during the scaling. More serious brain storm meeting is required for clearing this obstacle. There is a good thing to share is Juno RPC had pass through Starknet stress testing on Sepolia network with a decent result. Especially at the 2nd round after we increased feeder timeout and added CPUs which learnt from the 1st round of testing. 
Stakeholder Satisfaction: 🟡
• Infrastructure - 
Investigations into Juno's VM configuration and HPA triggers has been done. We fund there is no much difference so we'll continue using the existing trigger—average CPU usage. A sad fact remain is each new pods require 2-3 mins for scaling. Ideally it could be improved. on the other hand, infra cost had reduced a lot since we switched the api gateway. we are now saving about 260 USD per day compare to last month.
• Development - A new meeting has been arranged with Juno team and RPC team for looking new potentials for resolving the heavy multi-call + sticky session issue; 
• Support - All clients are well maintained so far no issue with supporting.
Timeline: 🟡
• Performance challenges continue to delay progress of the service. 
Scope: 🟢
• Performance Optimization - Ongoing testing and configuration adjustments in Juno and HPA are aimed at reducing the impact of heavy multi-call operations.
• Deployment Stability - Efforts are focused on refining deployment processes and addressing issues with autoscaling and VM management.
• Product maturity  - we start putting effort on building automated test suite for NM RPC to ensure future smooth upgrade.
Staffing: 🟢
• Key contributors are actively engaged in discussion for looking for solution for the performance challenging. meanwhile, they are actively helping other projects for best utilise their skills and time.

Overall Status: 🟡 The RPC project remains at Amber due to ongoing performance challenges related to heavy multi-call operations. The team is investigating potential solutions involving the Juno configuration and High Performance Autoscaling (HPA) triggers to improve response times and reduce failed requests.
Stakeholder Satisfaction: 🟡
• Infrastructure - The team continues to address performance issues, focusing on optimizing the deployment of new pods during high-load scenarios. A recent stress test revealed the need for faster scaling, and further tests are being planned.
Investigations into Juno's VM configuration and HPA triggers are ongoing, with initial results suggesting that current settings may be too optimistic, causing delays in scaling.
• Development - A proof of concept (POC) is underway to explore using vm_queue as an HPA trigger. Early findings indicate challenges with the current configuration, particularly when handling spikes in heavy multi-call requests.
The team is evaluating the use of Blockifier's concurrent execution feature to improve performance.
• Support - Continuous efforts are being made to assist users, with specific attention to CORS-related issues following the Juno upgrade. The team is coordinating closely with stakeholders to address these concerns promptly.
Timeline: 🟡
• Performance challenges continue to delay progress. The team is conducting tests and implementing configuration changes to improve system responsiveness under heavy load.
Scope: 🟢
• Performance Optimization - Ongoing testing and configuration adjustments in Juno and HPA are aimed at reducing the impact of heavy multi-call operations.
• Deployment Stability - Efforts are focused on refining deployment processes and addressing issues with autoscaling and VM management.
Staffing: 🟢
• Key contributors are actively engaged in testing and troubleshooting. Adjustments have been made to task assignments to ensure continued focus on resolving high-priority issues.

We have quickly added support for starknet new network Sepolia in staging and going to add it to prod after pass testing. Challenging remains but we are progressing well.

On application side, the service registration portal development almost completed although there is no purchasing feature temporary. on infrastructure side, the current sprint goal was not achieved therefore have to be carry on. The main issues are: we still looking for the best resolution for the traffic distributing which could keep both our clients and ourselves happy; and our horizontal pod autoscaling solution still have not deployed to production yet duo to a miss-considered limitation on GCP. but the good thing is, our current prod capacity is big enough to handle all client traffic and we have a clear update plan for the HPA solution;

after extensive testing, we have worked out an ideal initial infra capacity for serving potential big client's traffic. The new nodes have been successfully and smoothly deployed to prod for mainnet and goerli. Our horizontal pod auto scaling solution also had been tested well in staging and going to be deployed to production in recent days. The latest result is about 6-7 mins for new pod become available to serve client. Meanwhile, we are going on continues safety improvement and client custom requirements. Next step, we are going to build our own ETH L1 node to eliminate the independence of infura subscriptions.

Project is progressing as plan but urgently need to make a decision on ideal vertical computer size for single pod and the initial pod quantity in order to smoothly handle our first big client' traffic as well as not spending too much money. On the other hand, the short term horizontal auto-scaling solution has been tested in DEV env and need to be deployed to Prod asap. In addition, after further analysing, we notice that we are going to face bottle neck of L1 node traffic requirement with Infura plan, we need to create our own ETH L1 node as early as possible.

We are primarily focused on the solution for a fast horizontal scaling. After tons of testing and trying, the team had found a solution which is even better than planed. The POC has been passed and we are working on implement it on dev env now. on other hands, many customisation requirements come to our API management system are all achieved by our devops engineer as expected.

Project phrase 1 was completed as expected, monitoring and alerts are in placed, we are working on adding fire wall and special rate limits for enhancing security, meanwhile, we are working on horizontal auto-scaling resolution implementation.

We have complete the API Gateway setting for all environments all networks and tested working. Right now we are ready to provide user RPC SaaS new entrypoint  which is protected with apikey. On the other hand, engineers is working on implementing the solution for 0 downtime production horizontal scaling. We also have got the proper monitoring and alerting in place for the infra. more security solution has been designed and to be applied early next week. The project status is back on green.

We finally had made the choice for API management solution (Apigee). we have enabled the product and going to deploy RPC API on it soon. There were new high priority requirements came up so we are several days behind the previous expectation but there is no more solid blockers on the journey. all main stories (api, monitoring&alerts, ci/cd, firewall, infra optimization) are progressing gradually. We also have put quite a lot of effort on sorting the design of user onboarding with voyager team and have got an agreed sequence diagram.

We still could not decided which API management solution to use due to the fact that the previous preferred option turns out also cost too much and the Apigee from google shows much better features and design that seems suits us better. The downside of Apigee is it could become really expensive when the amount of requests become too big. We need to have internal meeting to make the choice 1st week Oct to move to next step. Apart from this, all other aspects of the project are progressing well.

Our current sprint goal only partially achieved because the API Gateway could not been selected in time. The reason caused this is because we started it before the client journey work flow was clearly designed. This is a lesson learnt. The good news is we now have got an agreement on the solution design from client onboarding to billing process. The sprint goal will be carry forward to the next sprint. We had very promising meetings done with the API Gateway providers and Voyager team. We have come up solution which not only could speed up the project delivery but also bring benefits to Nethermind future products. I expect the future sprints will have much better performance.

All team members are making progress, the sprint goal has been definited: Clear critical bugs, enable API keys, and have the basic log of infra and service captured, monitored and alerts enabled. and it should be achievable. API gateway investigation was taking a bit longer than expected but has been told there is a conclusion today. we should still have enough time for implementing.

Milestone 1 was achieved. Endpoints for all environment were released for clients to try. Apply Scrum project management framework for rest of the journey. New epic with tasks were created to aim better maturity - robust, requests recognisable and manageable.

EigenLayer AVS Operator status (https://.Status Context:
Last week, we faced multiple high-priority updates and deployments. We successfully handled an EigenDA migration for the Etherfi<>Nethermind operator within a week’s notice, as well as two mandatory updates—one for Lagrange SC with three days' notice and another for Aethos with less than 24 hours' notice. Additionally, we deployed the eigen-minter cronjob on Holesky for the EigenLayer Foundation before the Friday deadline, developing the code and deployment from scratch in under a week. We also managed to run a test disabling roots posted by the rewards-updater over the weekend, despite the short notice on Friday.

However, some critical tasks remain pending. We were unable to complete the deployment of Hyperlane and eOracle for the Etherfi<>Nethermind operator as planned. The urgent request to deploy eigen-minter on Mainnet has not yet been fulfilled. We also experienced delays in deploying Espresso nodes for the Decaf Testnet, which were further compounded by an Infura outage due to rate limits that affected much of our infrastructure at the end of the week. These setbacks have impacted overall progress and will require immediate attention to get back on track.

• We are trying to get involved in Symbiotic. HyveDA (equivalent to EigenDA) should be our first operation in late October.
• Etherfi agreement almost signed. This agreement defines an SLA, NDA, and rewards format for both CL validators and AVSs. Etherfi wants us to run two more AVSs for our shared Eigenlayer Operator.
• Espresso is finally launching the official testnet by late September and Mainnet by mid Octuber. We have asked for details on the incentives model.
• We have been building two essential projects for the AVS Operator monitoring (cardinal to comply with Etherfi SLA and keep Operator Top performance): an RPC proxy and an AVS Smart Contracts events metrics scrapper and exporter (https://github.com/NethermindEth/eigenlayer-onchain-exporter/pull/3).

Yield-Angkor collaboration is ongoing for risk research purposes as well as strategic prioritization. Two main shifts in strategy ahead:
• Being onboarded as Symbiotic operators: need to get the Devnet set up in preparation for mainnet operator launch.
• Becoming more selective with onboarding new AVSs.

Cairo Native Integration Status (https:/.Status Context:
The work on benchmark continues, we have detected several libfuncs in Native which are considerable slower than the VM. Nonetheless, Native is still faster than the VM overall. This means that Native is fast but it still can be faster.

We will follow on this with extra  benchmarking, either from Mainnet or Sepolia. We have discussed with LambdaClass the chance of formally adding benchmark tests to specific functions so that they can exists for the posterity.

Secondly, we also got into meetings with LC alongside Starkware to discuss Native user experience and other performance improvements that can be done. For example, after compiling a contract not all compilation artifacts are stored which it would be good if they were.

Finally, we are still testing Native for behaviour but there are still some issues. We added Sepolia support to our testing tool to be able not just to check for real world usage but also specific type transaction that doesn’t exist in Mainnet, like blocks of just Cairo 1 transactions.

The integration towards Starkware blockifier continues. The first PR is already merged, we are now in the working on the second one. During the past week has been a lot of back and forth, discussing the best way to integrate and polishing little details like exactly how to update the CI when using Native.

On the other hand, we’ve already built a way to benchmark results with the Blockifier and Native. So far we’ve been benchmarking results of blocks in Mainnet. Nonetheless we couldn’t get very clear results due to the existence of Cairo Zero which takes ome benchmarks. To address this we are now going to switch to Sepolia and try some blocks that use only Cairo 1 specifically and compare the results between Native and VM

We have succesfully moved integration outside of Native which means the Blockifier is looking like the final product. We are now focusing on updating to Cairo 2.7.0 (hopefully LC will merge soon) which means we will have the final version of the blockifier. PRs will roll out immediatley after that.

On the other hand we are upgrading Juno (in a development way and not in a production way) to have a persistent storage cache, this way we can greatly reduce the time spent compiling contracts which will allow us for faster testing and pinch the real improvements of Native over the VM.

Finally, we will slowly start (and gain momentum through the coming weeks) to test the blockchain using our tool. There are still runtime & compilation bugs in Native that needs fixing. At the very least we can pin-point all(most of) the issues in Native to create awareness about them

We have the following three major important features close to merging, but not there yet:
1. Mocking execution resources for Cairo Native
2. Fixing an error in the Fallback Mechanism
3. Moving Cairo Native compilation outside of the Blockifier

On parallel with this we have made improvements to comparison tool which are making it a lot more usable.

We are waiting for Cairo Native to update to Cairo 2.7.0 in order to start rolling PRs to Starkware Blockifier. We will need to first update ourselves to Native and Blockifier as well first)

As soon as this things get fixed and PRs start rolling we can focus on sampling the network and finding unknown issues.

The past week wasn’t the slowest nor the fastest. 
We have improved our testing tool, so far though, we cannot test it fully due to LambdaClass not supporting MacOS. A team member is testing it with linux but progress has been slow.

On the other hand we are improving the Cache mechanism that we initially had on the blockifier, so we don’t need to re-compile every contract a-new each time we trace/replay a block.

We also have a team member focused on fixing the errors of Native we are having.

Finally, it is worth noticing that timelines are shaky, we are a trinity of teams (SW, Neth & LC). Ideally, LC would finish, then we would complete our and finally SW will integrate with Centralized Sequencer. 
Practically, that would increase time to make integration so we are trying to parallelize as much as possilbe and to be on par with LC as much as possible, sometimes. 
This has the cons of breaking changes and making past efforts to be wasted.

Luckily enough the next planned update is Cairo Native for the blockifier so SW team will stop pushing updates for Cairo and will participate in the integration into the Sequencer.

We are being slowed by the fact that Cairo Native has some bugs. They are also very obscure and hard bugs, which doesn’t make it easy for us either to help them fix.

On the other hand our testing tool for replaying the network has been made public and considerable improvements have been added to it.

Everything is in a good pace. We are focusing on:
1. Finishing the Testing Tool
2. Finding some bugs in the Blockifier and fixing those

There are three lines of active development
1. Improve the stability of our automated testing tool
2. Debug errors in Cairo Native
3. Debug errors in the Blockifier

Currently (1) & (3) are going relatively well. Good advances on both fronts. 

(2) is given more trouble due to the steep learning curve of getting into a project of Cairo Native. Also we are not focusing too much into that as for now.

There is 4th line of research which is checking out the time complexity/improvements of Cairo Native over the normal blockifier.

Finally, Xander, our new hire, is getting up to speed with the project remarkably fast!

This week the team mainly focused on the tool for testing the blocks, which is nearly functioning as intended. The next steps regarding this tool would include improving the output and refining other minor details.
The bug related to the Braavos Account was successfully fixed at the beginning of the week by LC team 🎉.
Currently, the Blockifier is running slower with Native compared to the VM, which suggests we need to work on the integration so it is as efficient as possible. The team has already done some profiling to identify potential areas for improvement.

Everyone’s setup in the team is working properly now, which should allow them to move forward. The team has developed a tool using simulateTransaction which allowed them to continue testing the blocks, this is still in a very basic state, so the team will be working on it. They’ve already found some issues while executing a block and will be looking into them next week.
We haven’t heard from LC yet about the issue regarding Braavos Account

If I could, I would set the status to yellow greenish, instead of amber. This week started less than ideal with still many tests to do in Cairo Native. Nonetheless, during the curse of the week things have been starting to look brighter.

We have started to run some blocks and we have gotten many transactions to successfully compile and execute. Nonetheless we are still blocked by Braavos Account related transactions, since Braavos Account seems to trigger a compilation bug in Native. Still, we are pretty sure of the cause of the error and the LC Team is making our issues their priority 🫶. 

Also, we have run different blocks and find out that most of the time Braavos is the blocker, but that other contracts have the same bug. The good news here is, so far, just one compilation bug  detected 🥂. 

Next week goal is to try and detect all possible compilation & runtime errors. For that we will try to run all the blocks starting 610_000. This will open up errors and new lines of investigation.

We are moving slower than expected. At this point we should have already tested a couple of transactions but problems with Native and outdated versions of mlir has been difficult. Also, numerous issues on compiling the Juno node with the native blockifer and slow sync times.

To solve the first issue we are updating to the latest version of Native and the blockifier. Hopefully it can fix the issue with compilation.

Regarding slow compilation times, we are now downloading Juno Snapshots to avoid the syncing time.

All issues regarding Juno integration has been solved. The whole team is now moving towards testing Mainnet. We are all syncing local Juno nodes. Also, compiling juno “native” nodes, there are some small issues with the compilation, specifically with MLIR dependencies. On the other hand, we have been working on a tool to automatize the process of testing.

We are behind on schedule on connecting the Native-Blockifier with the Juno node. There have been several reasons for this:
- Technical difficulties: understanding the whole Juno architecture and how to change it so it triggers the right response of the Native Blockifier. The inter-language communication made this a little hard to pinpoint. With the help of Kirill we know where to program now.
- Other Non Cairo Native issues such as team members taking vacations, new hires which requires training and extra interviews which require time.

We are still trying to figure out how to correctly integrate the new blockifier into Juno. Since the  native-blockifier expects Sierra and the normal one expects CASM, we need to investigate how to make Juno give Sierra (instead of Casm) to the blockifier when tracing transactions/blocks.

On the other hand we have wrote detailed reports of Native errors and Lambda Class has fixed a bunch of them (others still in the pipeline though). Among the things found was a small inconsistencies in the blockifier code

The team is focusing on three fronts:

1. Updating the latest Native version (that uses Cairo version 2.6.3). This will also allow us to update the latest version of the blockifier. Currently facing with issues regarding Native execution. We are investigating them and in constant communication with the Native team.

2. Extracting all transactions starting from v0.13.1. If the blockifier is ever going to be ready for production it must first be able to reproduce most of mainnet. We are working along side Voyager and Juno team to solve this on parallel lines of investigation.

3. We are making atomic PRs to the Starkware blockifier so they can be reviewed more easily

• Full test suite for OpenZeppelin contracts - complete

Libre research status (https://www.notio.Status Context: Completed
The research is now finished, findings are with Avtar

Research
• The granularity proofs, now we can generate proofs with mutiple merkel trees.
• Working on generating the proof on front end instead of backend for the public chain case.
• Some interns-frinedly tasks in case we have some interns interested on ZK stuff

The approach for phase 2 will be:
1. Not having a dedicated tree for review_date. Let's assume that once the review_date has come, and a user has not updated his documentation on time, he is added to the blocked sparse tree. This way, the user would not be able to generate a proof-of-NON-membership against this tree and he would not be able to trade. Pros: No work needs to be done, and we save one merkle proof from being proven in the ZK circuit. Cons: We need to make sure the tree is always updated (also true for other flags).
Research on the phase 2 is going well.
Progress gradually

Paprika status (https://www.notion.so/Pa.Status Context:
Gathered a quorum to decide next steps. The next one is merge into Nethermind which is happening at the moment. We agreed to 2 weeks to 4 weeks with @Marek Moraczyński and @Daniel Celeda for finalization and merge with the node. 

After this week I can tell that the merge to Nethermind process is going much smoother than I anticipated and we’re at 80% done. I'm amending a few bits in Paprika to make it fully aligned with the required APIs. I believe the beginning of the next week (Mon, maybe Tue) we should have the first run over migrated Sepolia. 

The process does not cover synchronization now, but the plan is to have the node synced, migrated using Paprika.Importer and then follow with having it run.
Even though several attempts were taken to make the database much smaller (and the actual data in Paprika database are) the Sepolia database is still at 22GB-24GB and cannot get lower atm.

Migraged the Sepolia databae. It takes ~1h on my hardware to make it. Even though the internal data of Paprika occupy ~13GB the database as the whole takes 23GB on disk which is more than 80% of Sepolia’s RocksDb. Digging further what is the reason for having such a massive overhead.

Massive improvements in speed of Paprika by making the Merkle parallel. Additionally, one correctness bug fixed. The importer work takes much more time than anticipated due to problems with Sepolia network that is quite often not syncing. Then, after a sync it took me 2 days to make the importer run in any form
The work on importer is ongoing and requires introducing a new visitor to Nethermind.
Dry runs & testing showed 2 serious bugs. One with the correctness, the second with Merkle getting really slow after some period of time. Both fixed but still the importer is not done yet.

Should be storing the real database now already. Still requires more testing with full Merkle and running the load with Merkle/Sepolia. Tests show some overhead with fully connected scenario (Merkle construct stored etc). I plan to have the test run next week.
Full Merkle working in Paprika, storing the intermediate nodes (and hashes if needed) in the Block component. The block component is properly squashed to the database.
Very good progress on Merkleization. Huge fuzzing tests working as expected. Parity with Nethermind client TrieNode achieved in regards to the root hash calculation of the state trie.
Very good progres on the Merkle tree. Got a reproduction of a massive account tree and compared roots with Nethermind. Now moving forwards into the deletes of the nodes.

The Merkle aspect of Paprika takes much more than anticipated. The dirty tracking of changed nodes became quite complex and I needed to make a step back to make it simpler and more succinct. 
The next week should tell where we’re at. The plan was to have the Merkle construct running by the end of July. It might be hard to reach but we’ll see. The Merkle part might require use parts of Nethermind to compare the values properly.
People-wise we’re good, but we might be looking for a core team member to chime in soon to do provide and additional pair of eyes.
OOO for the only engineer on the board

Good communication with EF, sent a large update on where we are and asked for adjustment in the grant milestones. 
@Lautaro Emanuel is pausing his efforts in the project with me getting OOO for 2 weeks. We will see if we’ll get him back depending on the Merkle work and his involvement in other activities.
I’ll be moving on with Merkle after getting back.
I was considering giving 🟢this time but I think it would not be objective after 3/5 of week.

The Merkleization work didn’t happen as soon as expected. It’s not a trivial task, but after doing the book keeping in https://github.com/NethermindEth/Paprika/issues/77 it will require more work.

I engaged with EF Grant providers to share more news and provide some updates. This is an ongoing effort. Also, in the non-engineering area got a great cooperation with @Anneli Nowak in regards to the marketing. A Twitter thread appeared and we’re preparing the PR.

Huge results after last round of testing. Paprika run with a number of accounts equal to Ethereum mainnet which makes it look strong. The storage is not there and Merkle and a few optimizations but this is a massive achievement.

Why 🟡 then? Due to the Merkle stuff.

The work for Keccak is not done and with the late update on Friday it’s quite unlikely to be implemented this week. I set a soft deadline for the following features at the end of this week and will provide a longer assessment by the end of week:

1. 250-300 million accounts stored on a machine - results, benchmarks
2. Merkleization - where we're at
3. synchronization - what's possible, where we're at
4. Verkle potential

The Keccak/Merkle is not provided and it looks like it will take at least one more week to make it work. This is an optimistic take. Being given that the Merkle work is being in progress for 2 weeks now, I think it will take two weeks atm.

A good week with progress in area of the finalized blocks persistence. A lot of tests added, while still not running fully the Runner. This is a drag, but not that big to give it 🟡. Onboarded @Lautaro Emanuel and had chat about Keccak and Merkle construct. It looks like the next week we’ll be overlapping in our areas much more. Also, on Friday next week I’ll give a Tech Chat presentation so that more folks will be looking at Paprika.
The last thing is the legal work with @Julia Laganowska about a potential patent. This is done behind the scenes, but looks that potentially, maybe, if Paprika works we can get a patent there? Time will tell.

Some implementation progress in regards to the flushing mechanism and its understanding in other databases (LMDB, RavenDb). This resulted in separating the storage component that accumulates the changes in the db as a left-fold or a tail of state. Very good design discussion with other Core members resulted in a clean plan for handling NewPayload and ForkChoiceUpdate. Not that much code happened this week, but from the design pov the path is clear.
One person is being searched for for 1-2 weeks work in Paprika to implement the hashing and Merkle part.

The week ended with two tests. The first run with an assumed 40% of mainnet state&storage, the other run on a limited machine on Linux. Both of them showed Paprika working but once the memory budget is breached, the speed is limited by IO. A further research and learning is required to follow the discussion @Szymon Kulec started here https://twitter.com/Scooletz/status/1656732930532573201. The Keccak phase is paused for now till we get a clear understanding of where we are with IO and whether the mmap should be replaced with Direct IO.

Good progress on Storage. We’re almost there.
Good pivot towards a bit different model that allows more agility in regards to storing data.
Initial runs on bigger data sets (50 million accounts).
Looks optimistic and promising.

Huge wins! Reproduced and killed one memory leak which resulted in massive improvements in disk size (reduction by factor of 10x in one benchmark). Even though the main engineer was sick for 2.5 days, it was an awesome week for Paprika.

I give umber as when running performance benchmarks with reorg depth of 64 we hit some wall of file getting big and sparse. This is not a danger or something that stops us though. Requires reshuffling approach for storing data but does not look like something infeasible.
The biggest part of the Foundations milestone is taking a bit longer than anticipated. Overall the progress is good though. Green it is.

Lido Research status (https://www.notion.Status Context: We delivered our https://www.notion.so/a3bda813d54f4a7b98410dd950e07dbd?pvs=21 to a happy and sometimes impressed client. The research will be sent to the LEGO council to assess its quality, which should be quick. According to Vasiliy, the research should be well received. We expect smooth sailing for our final payment from here.

We are in the process of putting together our writings in a single deliverable and cleaning up. Will validate the final two tasks to Lido in this week’s call, and after that will focus on delivery on the 30th.

We are still working on finalizing all open tasks, of which only 3 remain and are either complete and under review or very close to being complete. We are also focusing on polishing. Delivery is scheduled for the 30th.
We have solved the tough parts of all of our outstanding research tasks, and are now headed into the cleanup phase. Delivery scheduled for August 30th.

We finalized very important questions on the bonding requirements for operating Lido courts. We shared a note with the Lido team, who reacted positively, and are waiting for more detailed feedback. We have 4.5 weeks to go and are roughly in line with the schedule agreed with Cameron—perhaps only a bit delayed on cleanup. I prefer to keep the status amber until we finalize all outstanding research questions (in 1.5 weeks) due to the lack of contingency time.

Had a meeting with the client that went well on the technical side. We asked for the feasibility of a two-week extension, but the client is unable to change it without a DAO vote. One option is for Lido contributors to informally advocate for an extension in the Lido forums and say that such a delay will not be impactful. The DAO should not oppose this. We will discuss this option internally.
We are still on track with the timeline proposed by Cameron, but since it is a tight timeline, the status remains yellow. 5.5 weeks to go.

We continue to make progress on outstanding tasks. We got help from Cameron on the project management front, who put together a timeline for us here: https://www.notion.so/e0ab93d7398d4bebbc483d8580d3be50?pvs=21

We should be able to finish the project in the remaining six weeks, but we have no time buffer for contingencies. We plan to ask Lido for a two-week extension on the deadline this upcoming week.

Although there is a reasonable timeline set up, we leave the status on amber until discussing the new deadline with Lido.

We had a meeting with the Lido team that went well---they seem to be engaged and sharing useful feedback on the cryptoeconomics of our research. 

Drafts with more precision and depth were shared with the Lido team on the details of our research. Furthermore, we are currently focusing on prioritizing the tasks essential for delivery instead of exploring new directions.

The project is still behind schedule, so status remains amber.

Research is moving along, but there is the concern that some discussions are still too superficial. We are working on a few fronts at once:
- We are writing analyses of our court mechanism, from the points of view of bonding and evidence required by the courts. Coming up is a note on the operator’s economic incentives to white labeling.
- We are looking at the tools from our Phase 1 research that can be used for decentralized juror onboarding.
- Finally, we are looking at the features that can be used at the networking level to profile validators.

We will provide deeper analyses on these points throughout the week and reassess the situation.

We were able to bring our three research directions back on track. This week in particular, we were able to improve the quality of communication with the Lido team. We shared some of our open questions, and they proposed that we draft our ideas/solutions so that they can have a look and comment or collaborate as well. This is quite positive for us, since we encountered some friction early on when requesting feedback from them. 10 weeks to go.

Regarding the three fronts of research that were identified last week (court creation, SBT mechanism, heuristics), the last one has been prioritized the least. As it turns out, it is essential that we gain clarity on the heuristics mechanism first in order to make progress with the court design. We are setting the status as “amber” in order to point out that the priorities need to be rebalanced.

Good progress on the project. A rough architecture of the final solution has been shared with Lido, and their team is satisfied with the proposal. We have 12 weeks to go and 3 research directions to narrow down: Kleros court integrations, heuristic considerations, and SBT recommendations.

Finalizing the last theoretical concerns before discussing mechanism design. Project seems to be on track with the timelines. A concern is that we need to analyze what will be done regarding the ML model with Rated. We expect to reach conensus this week.
The team is making progress on highlighting and analyzing the important research problems at hand, such as p+epsilon attacks.

Lately, a considerable amount of time has been spent discussing non-technical issues related to legal regulations of decentralized justice protocols. The team has already scoped out this landscape to an acceptable degree—further research on the matter is a distraction. 

Measures have been taken to correct course and come back to the important technical questions that are our main objectives.
